It is an accepted nature of computing that
the average minimum requirements of new software

rise over time as the amount of computing
power you can get per dollar increases.

Anyone stuck on the low end for any specific
reason has likely been frustrated with this

as the internet's hype cycle moves to heavier
and heavier games.

The other part of this process that genuinely
frustrates me is that the select multiplayer

games that manage the colossal task of creating
a stable community that can last many, many
years thus

making them lifestyle games need to go through
a constant very subtle upgrading process which

slowly but surely raises the minimum requirements
of the game.

This is why CSGO would hardly work as well
on its original minimum requirements,

or why Fortnite is so hard to run on 4 GB
when it once was so easy.

This process makes sense when you think about
the way the game market works but can be a

bit frustrating when you think of how it can
unintentionally leave behind a lot of players

in developing countries were consoles are
way too expensive and PC components harder
to find.

So it would be very interesting if there was
some lifestyle game that in a way went backwards
on that process.

From what I can tell PUBG Lite is actually
PUBG Mobile recompiled for PC.

When Android Mobile released there were plenty

you could get a relative weaker PC to emulate
pubg mobile rather than play full-fat PUBG...

although that would incur some tremendous

So it seems to be they got PUBG mobile with
all its performance optimisation and recompiled

Lite.

Full location on screen right now.
The main file is called GameUserSettings.ini.

Sadly when they blocked all texture and LOD

have done the same here but you can still
lower the internal render resolution under
the ingame's 70% by changing these two lines.
I set both to 30% which represent 30% and 720p.

and got to testing the two

Ignoring the ultra-low resolution it looks
like in terms of textures and LOD it seems

the game already applies a lot of the stuff
that you could load via configuration file
on full pubg years ago.

The grass is reduced to this flat plane and
trees are rendered on really low LOD values.

Since the target user of this game cares more
about performance than fidelity it makes sense

but I can't help but wish regular PUBG also
included this option.

In terms of performance, the result was franquly
better than expected.

Most the time the actual FPS was floating
somewhere around 30 to 40 which on this definitely

double what I was expecting and within playable
levels.

There are instances of slowdowns, mainly when
a new part of the gigantic map is loaded and

you can absolutely feel this when driving
any vehicle, especially if you are in squad

mode and putting extra strain on your PC by
tracking your allies

but rarely will you see this on foot on a
regular match.

You might also notice this at the lobby when
all the players are squeezed together in the

same space but rarely will that be recreated
in actual gameplay.
